Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Investigating the mechanisms of visual working memory by testing predictions of a computational model
Award.AbstractNarration:
Successfully interacting with the environment depends upon the ability to briefly retain information in visual working memory. This form of memory is characterized as a balancing act, with the maximum resolution of each memory being constrained by the total number of objects stored. How this trade-off is implemented in the brain remains an open question and one that is vital to developing accurate theories of memory. The goal of this project is to better understand this trade-off between quality and quantity by testing memory recall in individuals with brain damage. The effects that the brain damage has on memory precision will provide insights into how visual working memory storage is implemented in the brain. This research will be conducted in collaboration with Dr. David Shum, an expert in memory research at Griffith University in Brisbane, Australia.

To better understand the mechanisms underlying the trade-off between the quality and quantity of memories stored in visual working memory, a simulated lesion model approach will be used. Behavioral data collected from individuals with brain damage performing a delayed estimation task, which measures the quality of an individual memory representation, will be compared to simulations from a computational memory model called the Binding Pool with varying degrees of simulated damage. The model predicts that damage to the individuation of memories causes binding errors, but only when multiple items are being stored. However, if there is damage to the visual features that support memory, then memory quality will be degraded regardless of the number of items being stored. The model?s simulations of the effects of brain damage will be compared to the memory recall performance of individuals with brain damage. Successful predictions of the model provide confirmatory support for this model of human memory. This NSF EAPSI award is funded in collaboration with the Australian Academy of Science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The NSF EAPSI program in Australia allowed me to collect some pilot data for my dissertation while working and living in Brisbane, Australia. Specifically, my research focuses on how visual information is bound together to form a memory representation, which is vital to understanding capacity in human visual working memory. My research in Australia with Dr. David Shum at Griffith University focused on developing and testing predictions of a computational model called The Binding Pool model (Swan & Wyble, 2014).

In this model, there are three components; the visual features that compose a memory representation, the layer of neurons where memories are maintained (i.e. the binding pool), and a layer of neurons that specifically individuate different memories called the token layer. A representation is formed when multiple visual features (e.g. color, orientation) are bound to a token in the binding pool. This architecture allows the model to simulate different visual working memory phenomena, including an important finding that there is a trade-off between the quantity of objects that can be maintained and the quality of each object.

The current project I am working on is to test predictions of the dissociation between the visual features and the tokens by comparing performance of the Binding Pool model to individuals who have brain damage using a lesion-model approach. The model predicts damage to either layer will independently influence the trade-off between the number of objects and the quality of each object. To test this prediction, participants were recruited from a hospital in Brisbane, Australia and performed a visual working memory recall task called delayed estimation (Wilken & Ma, 2004). In this task, participants remember either 1 or 3 colors and report a single color by selecting a color from a color wheel that best matches the color presented. In the preliminary data analyses, the individuals with brain damage show the expected pattern of less precision when there are 3 objects compared to 1 object. Importantly, some participants show patterns that match the predictions of the model. However, more data needs to be collected before any conclusions can be made. Collecting data from individuals with brain damage can sometimes be a slow process and I experienced a substantial delay while in Australia before I could begin data collection.

Fortunately, I was able to collaborate with Dr. Jennifer Fleming at University of Queensland to continue collecting participant data. One of the goals of this collaboration is to see if delayed estimation may be a more sensitive measure of visual working memory than other memory tests, such as the n-back task. A task with high degrees of sensitivity would be useful in assessment of the severity of brain trauma.

The NSF EAPSI program afforded me to opportunity to work with researchers outside of my field of Cognitive Psychology and learn how research is conducted on individuals with brain damage. While in Australia, I visited different research labs at the University of Sydney and the University of Queensland and presented my research project. I also presented this project to the department of Cognitive Psychology at Pennsylvania State University, where I received positive feedback in terms of the scope of the project. I really enjoyed my time in Australia and I know this project will be invaluable throughout my research career.

 


Last Modified: 03/21/2016
Modified by: Garrett Swan
